Trump Hands China A Gift In Dumping Trans-Pacific Partnership
Opinions expressed by Forbes Contributors are their own.
I write about international trade and investment.
This article is more than 4 years old.
Well, he’s done it. President Trump has withdrawn the United States from
“The Trans-Pacific Partnership is another disaster done and pushed by
special interests who want to rape our country, just a continuing rape of
our country,” Trump said last June.
Trump and his protectionist trade team have made it clear that their
principal goal is to stick it to China. Withdrawing from the TPP will have
exactly the opposite effect. It’s a gift to China and no one is happier
about it than the government of Chinese President Xi Jinping.
Speaking at the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum in Davos,
Switzerland last weekend, Xi said China would be happy to take over the
leadership role in global trade that the United States has now
relinquished. That will be good for China, but not so good for anyone
One of the main reasons that Japan, Vietnam and Malaysia chose to align
themselves with the United States by signing the TPP is that they didn’t
want to be left alone on a dark street with China. Several other East
Asian countries were expected to join TPP after it took effect, mostly for
the same reason. They wanted a continued U.S. presence in the region to
serve as an economic and strategic counterweight to China’s imperialistic
and bellicose designs. The Chinese want Asia all to themselves and Trump
The other parties to the TPP could decide to renegotiate it into an
agreement just among themselves, but alternatively some may feel they have
no choice but to join an alternative trade agreement being honchoed by
China – the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership or RCEP. It
includes 16 countries from India to Japan. It’s a wild-west sort of
agreement that cuts tariffs and leaves every man to himself to ensure he
doesn’t get cheated. It has no rules, no standards holding governments to
any threshold of ethical or honest behavior.
The TPP had rules. It had the highest standards ever included in a free
trade agreement – standards requiring governments to substantially up
their game on workers’ rights and environmental protection. This would
have reduced the incentive for American companies to off-shore jobs to
those countries. The TPP had stringent rules against blocking cross-border
data flows or censoring the internet. Small American businesses that
export to Asia rely on the internet for marketing, sales and shipping.
Without the TPP, they won’t have that protection.
All these rules and standards were fully enforceable. They gave the United
States the power to retaliate against countries that failed to live up
them. And 12 countries agreed to abide by them. Not only that, some
countries had started changing their domestic laws and regulations to
The Asia-Pacific is the world’s fastest-growing, most dynamic region. A
billion middle-class consumers live there and that number is expected to
triple by 2030. The 11 other TPP parties aren’t going to wait around for
the Trump administration to come to its senses. They will likely ratify
RCEP and hammer out bilateral and multilateral agreements of their own.
They may move forward with the TPP without us. Japan has already ratified
it. Tariffs against U.S. manufactured products and agricultural goods will
remain in place and American businesses, workers, farmers and ranchers
will be left out in the cold. American cattlemen lose $400,000 per day to
Australia in beef sales to Japan. The TPP would have given them a fighting
chance to compete for that market. Trump just took it away from them.
He also damaged America’s credibility, not just in the Asia-Pacific but
If the U.S. is “not prepared to deal when it comes to cars and services
and agriculture, can we depend on you when it comes to security and
military arrangements?” asked Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.
Since the end of World War II, the United States and its allies have built
and maintained a global economic and trade system that has served the
world exceedingly well. It made it possible for Europe and Japan to crawl
from the wreckage of the war and become prosperous and democratic. It has
helped billions of people escape poverty and join a burgeoning global
middle class. It served as a beacon of freedom that helped bring about the
collapse of the Soviet Union and the democratization of Eastern Europe.
By withdrawing from the TPP and pursuing an isolationist, “America First”
foreign policy, Trump seems intent on throwing that system in the trash.
This will give China an opening to run rough-shod over East Asia and
Russia to do the same in Europe.
Given his tenuous grip on reality, Trump may never come to regret this.
But the rest of us will.
